elasticsearch/values.yaml.message: I'm not an expert on JVM tuning, so there may be no reason to specify these options anymore. But would you please elaborate on why you remove these completely instead of specifying JVM version, like the others?

Elasticsearch image version 7.9.0 added mandatory bootstrap setting's check before start. These bootstrap checks inspect a variety of Elasticsearch and system settings and compare them to values that are safe for the operation of Elasticsearch. If Elasticsearch is in production mode, any bootstrap checks that fail will cause Elasticsearch to refuse to start. 
(https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/bootstrap-checks.html)
Because Elasticsearch image 7.9.0 has JVM version 14.0 it fails with previous jvm-options loaded from helm chart. To start elasticsearch-master pods without failures it needs to use default JVM options or custom options, but be ready that these settings may not pass bootstrap check.

JVM options, that I provided, are default options from Elasticsearch JVM config, and as Elasticsearch documentation says: "Elasticsearch includes default JVM options that work well for most production environments. If needed, you can override these default options using jvm.options files". Unfortunately, I don't have possibility to validate all possible versions and options compatibility for JVM 14 and Elasticsearch >= 7.7.0.

keystone/common/sql/contract_repo/versio.message: this is the only change that makes me a bit nervous

Hi Steve,

The bits I've added here are to remove and then add back the foreign key constraint around the table column alter for domain_id in the identity_provider table on line 35. InnoDB is very relaxed about these types of changes, while NDB is more strict. However, there are other examples of the proper flows being done when updating a table or column that has foreign key constraints. If you look at 014_contract_add_domain_id_to_user_table.py, you'll see that it does the FKC drops before making the table changes, which is the right way to do these table modifications. I've tested this on InnoDB and NDB, without any error messages in the db_sync operation. 

Let me know if you have any other concerns.

Thanks,
Octave
Assuming this can be documented, this probably belongs in keystone.common.sql.upgrades
I don't see a problem with that. Docs would be nice, too.
I did see this in a few other sqlalchemy scripts in Keystone. I do agree we should move this to a common place. Are you okay with me making that change as part of this patch?

For the duration of time that this constraint does not exist at the database level, is the application enforcing a similar constraint? I wouldn't want L38 to fail because an invalid project ID was slipped into this table.

I haven't seen any examples of Keystone or other services doing anything intelligent in these use cases where a constraint is dropped, table is changed, and then the constraint is recreated. There are other examples in keystone already that do this, look at 014_contract_add_domain_id_to_user_table.py for example.
only  "if ndb.ndb_status(engine)", drops and recreates like these can be non-performant, lock tables, etc. and are unnecessary
This is something that should be fixed regardless of NDB. There are actually other examples of foreign keys being dropped and recreated in Keystone. This one was just missed for some reason.
Same as the other file -- which is why this deserves to be in a common module.
++ I'd like to see this somewhere common instead of duplicating code.
all of this must be only for ndb, the autoloads here, changes, adds, drops, all take time and are complex

There are other examples in Keystone where foreign keys are dropped and recreated around tables changes. These ones were missed for some reason. If we want to do something smart here, perhaps we should have oslo.db intercept these kinds of table changes and do the right thing with foreign keys. If you're looking for an example of this elsewhere in keystone already, you can look in the scripts:

014_contract_add_domain_id_to_user_table.py
092_make_implied_roles_fks_cascaded.py

Point here is that this isn't specific to NDB. InnoDB is a bit forgiving around this. If we want to make the databases more portable, we should be following proper SQL flows when updating stuff.

OK, I'm going to pull the "reduce boilerplate" handle on this one again, this is all kinds of detailed, brittle stuff that can be 100% automated.   Internally it should be using alembic ops so that we don't need to go through the whole effort of autoloading the whole table which is completely unnecessary.

the one feature that isn't built into SQLAlchemy reflection right now is the ability to locate all the referents for a given column, so the API function will for now still refer to the names of tables we care about.  however, it can do everything else internally quite simply and will look like this:

    from oslo_db.sqlalchemy.util import recreate_fks

    with recreate_fks(
        migrate_engine, "user_table", 
        referents=[
            "local_user", "nonlocal_user", "project"
        ]):
        user_table.c.domain_id.alter(nullable=False)

isn't that a lot nicer / easier to read?

keystone/common/sql/migrate_repo/version.message: Are we allowed to make modifications to this repo now that we have switched to using the rolling upgrade model?

I've had to make this change so that the base database schema will work with MySQL Cluster (NDB). It only affects the setting of the mysql_engine setting based on the mysql_storage_engine setting from oslo.db in the keystone.conf file. It shouldn't change anything for users who are using MySQL (InnoDB).

OK.  So I would propose that passing through "mysql_storage_engine" plainly like this is too fine grained.  It implies that someone could stick "MyISAM" or "ARIA" in there, which is not the case; things will break badly.  In oslo.db, the fact that one wants to use "ndb" should be a coarse-grained configuration setting; "CONF.database.mysql_use_ndb"; then here, mysql_engine would call upon an oslo_db function called "get_effective_mysql_engine(conn)" - it's passed a Connection or Engine (migrate_engine here is an Engine).  Connection/Engine.info will have the "use_ndb" flag inside of it which was set up within oslo.db.engines.create_engine().   This allows the consumption of CONF.database.* to remain local to the Engine object that gets set up without a separate need to track CONF.* settings to it; then oslo.db is called upon to make the determination what it means to be "ndb" or "non ndb".

When using Calico as CNI, this change will cause inter-node networking to break in some cases as calico-node may use the extra interface for cluster traffic, therefore being blocked by port security.

Calico-node's IP_AUTODETECTION_METHOD will need to be added to specifically exclude the extra_network interface or subnet.

I was able to get it to work by setting IP_AUTODETECTION_METHOD to 'skip-interface=<extra net interface>'.

neutron/db/provisioning_blocks.py.message:
So this change doesn't really fix https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1953478. In this change you are just adding:

1) The provisioning completion for ports that don't require provisioning blocks
2) A log statement for the case when we don't find the provisioning block

With this, it seems that https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/824982/2/neutron/agent/dhcp/agent.py#403 is what is going to address https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1953478

Am I understanding right?

Not exactly. This patch is actually fixing the root cause of the https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1953478 which is: change port's status when "unexpected" provisioning complete message was sent to the server (like in case of the bug it was unexpected provisioning complete by the DHCP entity).

Then, patch https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/824982/2/neutron/agent/dhcp/agent.py#403 is fixing the cause of this specific, "unexpected" provisioning complete message, so I would say that https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/824982/2/neutron/agent/dhcp/agent.py#403 fixes what triggered that error with shelve/unshelve instance.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
I think we need to split this problem into smaller chunks. The easiest way I can think of doing that is to now do the enforce_scope_check=True thing yet. Lets focus instead on enforce_new_defaults.

I am bit worried the keystone roles are not as we expected for the transition plan that has been agreed, and may need tweaking, but that should be easier without enforce_scope_check.

Looking at the yoga timeline, trying to work out what we need to do in kolla.

https://opendev.org/openstack/governance/src/branch/master/goals/selected/consistent-and-secure-rbac.rst#yoga-timeline-7th-mar-2022

* keystone will create the service role AFAICT, we should not need to do it.
  * TODO: Need to check that there is a DB migration that adds it for upgrades.
* Keystone sets keystone.conf [oslo_policy] enforce_scope = True, and removes deprecated policies
  * We need to ensure that we are ready for this. All use of keystone from that point will need to be using the correct scope.
  * We can test it by setting the two oslo_policy flags to true in keystone.conf. As JG says, we don't need to get there in one go.
  * The majority of this patch is about token validation (keystone_authtoken). I'd suggest we restrict it to that and split other things out.
  * Using the new service role seems like a good approach. I'm a little unclear on whether it should be system-scoped or project-scoped though. The current patch is using the service project. The policy docs allow any scope for identity:validate_token. We will need to provide some support for upgrades to add any new role assignments.
  * The current patch adds the new role assignments, but we'll also need to determine how and when to remove the admin role from service users.
Once we have a rough plan for yoga, it might be worth sharing and comparing with other deployment projects on the mailing list.

Dropping the admin role from service users that are only used for token validation might be a good way to validate this change. Service users that do things other than token validation might be more difficult (e.g. nova). Again, need to consider upgrades.
Still need to determine whether this should be in the service project, or with system scope.

The RBAC spec suggests that the service role will be used for 'service to service communication. It's not clear exactly what will be included in that. I think it's really a 'phase 2' thing, which is beyond Yoga. I'd certainly expect it to include token validation. When we're talking about creating and owning resources (networks, etc.), it seems likely we might be required to put them in a project.

I think it's worth noting that we're adding role assignments here - only when we try to remove the admin role will we find which users may need additional roles.

I suggest that while we try to get an answer for the project vs system scope question, we push on with other parts we need for Yoga.

The main thing that I see biting us is when keystone changes the default of enforce_scope (and enforce_new_defaults?). We need another patch, based on this one, that changes those defaults (unconditionally, since there will be no way back in yoga AFAIK), and makes any changes required for it to work. I think we had some of that code in here at some point.

I sent a message to the mailing list. Feel free to reply.

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2022-January/026777.html

Point of clarification - are we trying to determine for each service:
1. if the "service" role requires a project (vs system scope role)? 
2. if the service user requires "admin" role (also determining if project vs system scope) ?
 
It seems like each service might need a different set of roles - "service" role likely doesn't give enough access for nova, etc.

That's true. It certainly applies in some cases (e.g. octavia). In many cases however the service will only need to do token validation.

Maybe it's time to start a discussion on the mailing list?

We know that certain actions require a project, like making a network. 

https://github.com/openstack/neutron-lib/blob/master/neutron_lib/api/attributes.py#L266

"Running without keystone AuthN requires that tenant_id is specified"

Code looks good, assuming the service role is project-scoped. -1 until we get agreement on that (although I'm personally leaning towards system-scope and one ML response agreed).

If you're looking for something to do, it might be sensible to get a patch together that adds support for assigning roles with system scope in service-ks-register. Ideally we'd use the ansible module, but we've not pushed that forward. Most of the code should be present in previous patchsets. It would probably use input data like this:

# project-scoped
- username: foo
  project: bar
  role: baz

# system-scoped
- username: foo
  system: all
  role: baz
FYI: I'm pushing forward in openstacksdk for system scope role, hopefully landing in yoga timeframe. https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstacksdk/+/824470

Awesome 😊

Will there be a corresponding ansible module change?

The latest RBAC Conversations determined that system scope role has no project associated with it. After discussing with John G, to move toward the goals in https://opendev.org/openstack/governance/src/branch/master/goals/selected/consistent-and-secure-rbac.rst, we are trying to move service users to have service role and enabling enforce new defaults in keystone. This is part of phase 2 - Isolate service-to-service APIs to the service role. Adding the service role allows service users to validate tokens in keystone API  (https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/latest/configuration/policy.html). We are determining what the gaps are in the default Keystone policy from failing tests.

doc/source/contributor/process.rst.message: So this description states here what the problem was we wanted to solve with the review priority label. And below described our solution. Now you proposed additional things to the solution but it is not described here what was the original problem where we needed this new extended solution.
This is now in direct contradiction with the above added sentence

I think you trying to handle two cases here in single bullet making the bullet complicated:

* the commit author sets +1 on its own patch -> the author commits to answer review comments and provider new revisions if needed

*  a non core reviewer sets a +1 on a patch where they is not the author -> similarly to +2 it means the reviewer commits to help landing the patch by (re-)reviewing it frequently.

I suggest to handle these two cases in separate bullet points for clarity.

I had different experience. The etherpad had a long list of reviews waiting in the queue. So using it to asking for review wasn't a problem. The problem was (paraphrasing from above):

1) The list of patches in the queue needed to be regularly checked. Is this review still valid? Or is it in merge conflict? Or is it got review feedback already while sitting in the queue? Does the patch series has new patches in the middle? Does it now depend on another series that need to land first?
Unfortunately people are more motivated to add their stuff to the review queue than going back and update the queue if their patch is changed state. The PTL kept the queue in shape and that does not really scaled well.


2) The patch series that was selected for a review slot did not really get review attention. So they timed out in the slot and went back to the end of the queue. I, as a PTL, did not kicked the cores enough to look at reviews in the slot as I did not feel that it would be productive forcing people. I showed the content of the slots on the meeting to get attention but in my experience it did not really worked well to commit to reviews in the slot and then delivering on that commitment.

I agree that we might want that, I disagree that it is need to be implemented via the Review-Priority label. 

People can ping asynchronously via IRC. Most of the cores are keeping their clients up all the time and read the scroll back.

People can ping async via the ML. 

People can add certain reviewers to the patch in gerrit as reviewer or as CC. This is also async and close to the review system.

This is what I don't like. We have already a plethora of ways to express "I need reviews". 

What I agree with is that a non-core sets +1 to say, I as a non-core commit myself to (re)review this patch in the future, helping it to land.
let's add a sentence here like it is not to add RP as +1 on your own patch to get more review/attention from core.

what is the reason for excluding _config_out_of_date hosts? It could be the result of other pending runtime manifests about to be applied, and should be expected on configuration changes.  (This condition is also in the method _update_ptp_host_configs() above.
That makes sense, I'm going to test without that condition. Will update asap.

ic, this scenario should be rare and the host-unlock will ultimately apply the config.  This isnt generally required for other types of runtime config.  A comment would be helpful for future reference to understand why this condition is/was required.

Actually, looking at this again, it is there to prevent the runtime manifest from being applied when there is a pending reboot_required config and instead waits for the host unlock to apply the config instead.

Do you have any input on whether that is a necessary precaution, or should we just allow the runtime manifest to be applied at any time? I don't immediately see an issue with that, but the implementer for single instance ptp thought it was necessary.

Looking at this again, I think it's best to remove this condition. The reason being that ptp configuration is complicated and it's possible that the user could enter a configuration that might fail to apply properly. It is intended that they can use the runtime apply to check this, allowing them to correct any issue. Forcing them to use the unlock could result in a failure.

So it's much better to allow the runtime to apply at any point.

build-tools/stx/build-pkgs.message:
Each job is building a package, yes?   Do those jobs see all cpus?   If yes, than my concern would be with individual package builds using something like 'make -j<num-cpus>'
This can get quite bad if the number of cpus is large

32 cpu's -> 32 packages building in parallel -> 1024 copies of gcc running in parallel!  Too much!

I think I used something like jobs=min(<num-cpus>, sqrt(<num-cpus>)+1) to keep this in check on our larger machines.

No, currently multiple packages parallel building are not supported. The jobs here is 'number of parallel jobs' to build one package. This option '-j <jobs>' will be passed to 'dpkg-buildpackages', you can refer to the part '-j ,--jobs=n' of 'https://manpages.debian.org/unstable/sbuild/sbuild.1.en.html'. And part '-j, --jobs[=jobs|auto]' of 'https://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man1/dpkg-buildpackage.1.html'

"The cpu cores" here doesn't mean the 'host cpus cores' that the container can see with 'nproc', it comes from the ENV variable ‘MAX_CPUS’ which assigned by minikube's resource allocation in the merged commit: https://review.opendev.org/c/starlingx/tools/+/819608
This commit takes the 'sqrt' way to allocate the cpu resource to each container.

The reason why 'jobs' can be defined in the 'meta_data.yaml' of the package is that some packages do not support parallel builds, 'jobs: 1' in 'meta_data.yaml' can make it fallback to serial build.

Alternatively, or in addition, can you come up with a way for the owner of a shared machine to enforce a cap on the number of jobs available to a single build.

I have nightmares of designers on a large shared machine ... each seeing 64 cpus, and all requesting 64 jobs. e.g. 5x64x64=20000 jobs!!! and the system crashes.

"I have nightmares of designers on a large shared machine ... each seeing 64 cpus, and all requesting 64 jobs. e.g. 5x64x64=20000 jobs!!! and the system crashes."

hi, Scott, '5x64x64' here,  do you mean 5 users and each builds 64 source packages at the same time, and each package requires '-j 64' ? 

We don't want to support 64 packages to be built parallel, in future, the max number of parallel build source packages for a user should be 4, so the max jobs are:
5 users X  max 4 src packages X 64 <= 1280,  For a 64 cores machine, I think this is not too heavy.

What's your opinion? thanks

Thanks to review. The comments is not wrong. '4' is the default value if the ENV 'MAX_CPUS' does not exist. But it is very confirm that 'MAX_CPUS' will be export to ENV, so I will update this to "jobs = os.environ.get('MAX_CPUS')".
I don't see any limits being enforced on these values.  What prevents a request for far more jobs than the machine can handle?

To be honest, it is hard to choose such 'limit'. The original purpose to get the 'jobs' from meta_data.yaml is forcing to serial building mode if the package does not support parallel build. In most cases, there is no need to set 'jobs' in meta_data.yaml.  But if this is abused, even is used as attack way, I have nothing to say. And I am ok to drop the part to fetch the value from meta_data.yaml, only keep the part to assign 'MAX_CPUS' to jobs. what's your opinion?

Any guaranty MAX_CPUS is always going to be set? Or should we be doing something like the following?

jobs = os.environ.get('MAX_CPUS', '1')

Thanks Mark, from our design, it is very confirmed that the external 'stx' will pass the MAX_CPUS to the builder's ENV once run 'stx control enter <builder container>'. But without any doubt, giving a default value like '1' makes the code more robust. I agree to set it to '1' which is more reasonable and safe then '4'.

cinder/volume/drivers/storpool.py.message: I don't think this can be done by actually deleting the existing volume and just creating a new one with the same name. Will Storpool keep existing identifiers when this happens? (if it does, that would be pretty unique)

Well, this is how StorPool volumes and snapshots work best - the absolutely fastest and most reliable way to revert a volume to a snapshot is to recreate it - it is practically instantaneous, there is absolutely no data being transferred anywhere, just a couple of system tables with object versions being updated.

This would only be a problem if the volume is in a state different from "available" and "error", i.e. if it is attached somewhere... but I certainly do hope that no one will ever try to revert an attached volume to a previous snapshot, since this will break in all kinds of funny ways regarding the operating system's block cache - since the disk driver has no idea about the cache in the kernel's higher-level layers, it has no way to invalidate it, so if a volume's data changes, the operating system has no way of knowing that. This sounds like a one-way ticket for the data corruption express...

So, if the volume is not attached, recreating it from the snapshot does the job of practically reverting it to that snapshot. Other than the volume ID (which is part of the name of the underlying StorPool volume, so it is preserved) what are the "existing identifiers" that you are referring to?

So After functional testing I conclude that the debug param does take affect when specified as no on the Infrared command line.
Turning it into a flag will not help either since currenty without any param (as with a flag) it defaults to debug True.
So the only option to disable debug (at least currently) is by explicitly calling : --debug no

nodepool/elements/ping-sysctl-fix/instal.message:
This should be prefixed by '-' resulting in:

  -net.ipv4.ping_group_range = 0 2147483647

Per the PR in github https://github.com/redhat-plumbers/systemd-rhel8/commit/41a32aeaf5d33f253f48bfbe8d00de9d160985f7

I noticed it while preparing the patch and looked for the reason: it makes the sysctl setting non-fatal. If I understand correctly, it was prompted by failures to apply this sysctl from within containers: https://github.com/systemd/systemd/issues/13177

This didn't seem to apply in this case, I actually wanted the opposite, i.e. making sure that the sysctl was applied successfully, which is why I left out the leading dash.

Ok, now I see that: [1] is safe because this is calling the driver's "enable" method. For the "dnsmasq" implementation in Neutron (the only in-tree driver), the method is [2], that calls [3]. In [3], if the network does not have any subnet with DHCP enabled, it returns False and does nothing.

The DHCP agent will store in the cache this network, regardless of not having any subnet with DHCP. When the network is deleted or updated (admin_state_up=False), the method "disable_dhcp_helper" is called too, but the drivers skips this call too.

[1]https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/19a20eaca8a51d6c095a68970478de847fb256f5/neutron/agent/dhcp/agent.py#L403
[2]https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/ca90d8c041151efce19dea10758fa46a7d32cc39/neutron/agent/linux/dhcp.py#L271
[3]https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/ca90d8c041151efce19dea10758fa46a7d32cc39/neutron/agent/linux/dhcp.py#L264-L269

We do, yes, but as I commented we are still using this parameter in [1] and we can't remove this functionality.

"configure_dhcp_for_network" is called from two places:
1) "enable_dhcp_helper": the network passed comes from "safe_get_network_info". By default, we only pass networks with subnets with DHCP enabled. This one is safe.
2) "safe_configure_dhcp_for_network": this one is called from "sync_state". The network information passed to this method comes from the call to get_active_networks_info(enable_dhcp_filter=False). I'm investigating this now but this patch is not changing this functionality. We could maybe remove the "enable_dhcp_filter" but not in this patch.

This is not a matter of what methods are currently passing enable_dhcp==False but handling this possibility. This method "get_network_info" accepts "enable_dhcp" as "True", "False" and "None"; that means we are considering all possible parameter values. If callers are only passing "enable_dhcp=True" and "enable_dhcp=None", that's ok. Method code covers this parameter inputs.
This is just the input parameter possible values. Filtering out the "False" value will add more complexity to the code of the method.

Because enabling container-tools stream 2.0 enables it?

diskimage_builder/elements/bootloader/fi.message:
so, I think this is backwards. at least package wise.

You *can* boot a UEFI only system using an MBR partition *or* an GPT partition table (as long as the firmware properly searches for the efi partition label). You can't... really.. bios boot a GPT partitioned image. At least, as far as I'm aware. Or at least, if it *works* it likely is not a "good idea"™

The only intent with this package installing is to ensure /etc/grub2.cfg or /etc/grub2-efi.cfg is actually installed before running grub2-switch-to-blscfg. (with an explicit --config-file to override the wrong efi detection)

/etc/grub2.cfg and /etc/grub2-efi.cfg are currently identical, and maybe they will be going forward. One option is to assume this, don't install any packages, and just run:

  grub2-switch-to-blscfg --config-file /etc/grub2.cfg
